A **skeleton**, Z, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a magically-animated [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") creature that is part of the [zombie](/wiki/Zombie_\(monster_class\) "Zombie (monster class)") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class"). Skeletons resist [cold](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance"), [sleep](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance"), [poison](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance"), [death magic](/wiki/Death_resistance "Death resistance"), and [stoning](/wiki/Stoning_resistance "Stoning resistance") - they also count as [thick-skinned](/wiki/Thick-skinned "Thick-skinned"), specifically due to lacking any organic parts.

A skeleton has a weapon attack and a [slowing](/wiki/Slowing_attack "Slowing attack") touch that can remove intrinsic speed. [Chatting](/wiki/Chatting "Chatting") to a skeleton will freeze you in place for a few turns regardless of hostility, and [free action](/wiki/Free_action "Free action") will not prevent this.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Generation

Skeletons are not randomly generated, and only appear in [Orcus-town](/wiki/Orcus-town "Orcus-town"), where five will be generated on level creation.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) Skeletons are always created hostile, and are valid targets for [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph"), e.g. [polymorph traps](/wiki/Polymorph_trap "Polymorph trap"). [Polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling") multiple objects made of [bone](/wiki/Bone "Bone"), such as [unicorn horns](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn"), may also create a skeleton, similar to how [golems](/wiki/Golem "Golem") generate from polypiling other materials.

A normally-generated skeleton has a 1⁄4 chance of [generating with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") [leather armor](/wiki/Leather_armor "Leather armor"), and an independent 1⁄4 chance of either a [knife](/wiki/Knife "Knife") (2⁄3 chance) or a [short sword](/wiki/Short_sword "Short sword") (1⁄3 chance);[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) they will not be given a random [offensive item](/wiki/Offensive_item "Offensive item").

Skeletons [do not leave a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless") upon death.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

As of [commit f0698e1d](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/f0698e1dcaf6b6c6ca4762b3a8a74cff537d2d48), bone devils summon skeletons instead of [summoning demons](/wiki/Demon_gating "Demon gating").

## Strategy

Skeletons are not a great threat compared to the [shades](/wiki/Shade "Shade") in Orcus Town - their [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") is mediocre, and they also lack an [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)"). However, their ability to nullify speed still makes them dangerous; their stoning resistance also means that they can wield [footrice](/wiki/Footrice "Footrice") [corpses](/wiki/Corpses "Corpses"), so be careful not to leave any near one.

Skeletons make decent [pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet") if you happen to obtain one: they are [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong") [breathless](/wiki/Breathless "Breathless") and [inediate](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate"), can wield weapons and use their touch attack to slow monsters, and have valuable resistances. Unfortunately, they are also slow themselves and cannot wear armor, despite potentially generating with some.

## History

The skeleton first appears in [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Skeleton](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search/Skeleton "wikipedia:Special:Search/Skeleton")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Skeleton (undead)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skeleton_\(undead\) "wikipedia:Skeleton (undead)")***

A skeleton is the structural frame that supports the body of most animals. There are several types of skeletons, such as the exoskeleton (the stable outer shell of an organism); vertebrates have an endoskeleton with a vertical column, which forms a support structure inside the body and is typically composed of bone and cartilage (a rigid connective tissue). Animated skeletons often appear as a type of physically manifested undead in fantasy, gothic and horror fiction, and mythical art. Most such undead are human skeletons, but they can be from any creature or race found on Earth or in the fantasy world.

Animated human skeletons have been used as a personification of death in Western culture since the Middle Ages, perhaps influenced by the valley of the dry bones in the [Book of Ezekiel](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Book_of_Ezekiel "wikipedia:Book of Ezekiel"). Paintings of The Grim Reaper and Death of the [biblical horsemen of the Apocalypse](/wiki/Riders "Riders") have depicted them as skeletons.

Undead skeletons are used extensively in many fantasy role-playing games such as *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*. The basic skeleton is of the humanoid type and is commonly employed as a low-level undead enemy - they occasionally appear in groups, and are commonly armed with medieval weapons and sometimes armor. Skeletons debut in the 1st Edition Monster Manual of *Dungeons & Dragons*, where they appear in burial grounds, dungeons and other forsaken areas, and are enchanted with necromantic energy by a powerful evil magic-user or cleric. Skeletons could be given simple commands of 24 words or less by whoever animated, and would attack until they were destroyed; they were immune to mind-affecting spells and cold, and could only be damaged reliably by blunt weapons and fire. Holy water could damage skeletons, and non-evil priests like paladins or clerics could repel or destroy them outright.

## Messages

- The skeleton rattles noisily.

  You chatted to a skeleton.

- You freeze for a moment.

  You paralyzed yourself for a few turns as a result of the above.

## Variants

In variants that include the [Convict](/wiki/Convict "Convict") role, a skeleton is generated on the upper filler level(s) of the [Convict quest](/wiki/Convict_quest "Convict quest") at level creation.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") and [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), skeletons [require a +2 weapon or better](/wiki/Need_%2Bx_to_hit "Need +x to hit") to deal damage to them.

A sleeping hostile skeleton is always generated within the prison in the north half of [Grund's Stronghold](/wiki/Grund%27s_Stronghold "Grund's Stronghold") at level creation.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), skeletons are resistant to piercing and slashing weapons and vulnerable to blunt weapons.

Skeletons appear as the first [quest monster](/wiki/Quest_monster "Quest monster") for [Binders](/wiki/Binder "Binder"), and three skeletons are generated as attendants to the third altar on the goal level of the [Binder quest](/wiki/Binder_quest_\(dNetHack\) "Binder quest (dNetHack)"). Three skeletons appears accompanying a [death knight](/wiki/Death_knight "Death knight") within one of the rooms in [Demogorgon](/wiki/Demogorgon "Demogorgon")'s lair if his dwelling appears as [the third Abyss level](/wiki/User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Brine_Flats#Demogorgon.27s_palace "User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Brine Flats").

The presence of a [dread seraph](/wiki/Dread_seraph "Dread seraph") on a level causes corpses to rise from the dead as [zombies](/index.php?title=Zombie_\(dNetHack\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Zombie (dNetHack (page does not exist)") or skeletons. The [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") files of players killed by dread seraphs leave behind skeletons instead of [ghosts](/wiki/Ghost "Ghost").

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), skeletons can be summoned occasionally by [bone devils](/wiki/Bone_devil "Bone devil"), and may drop [skeleton keys](/wiki/Skeleton_key "Skeleton key") made of bone upon death.

If you chat to a skeleton while [hallucinating](/wiki/Hallucinating "Hallucinating"), the resulting bone-rattling will not immobilize you.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack-Rewrite](/wiki/SpliceHack-Rewrite "SpliceHack-Rewrite"), skeletons have their knife and short sword replaced with a [parazonium](/wiki/Parazonium "Parazonium") and [gladius](/wiki/Gladius "Gladius"), with the same odds of generating with each weapon.

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM details above, the second version of the [Mine king level](/wiki/Mine_king_level "Mine king level") has three skeletons hidden in closets.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), skeletons have the same odds of generating with a parazonium or gladius as in SpliceHack-Rewrite, and may also drop skeleton keys upon death like in xNetHack.

Grund's Stronghold contains the same sleeping skeleton as in SLASH'EM.

## Encyclopedia entry

A skeleton is a magically animated undead creature. Unlike  
shades, only a humanoid creature can be used to create a  
skeleton. No one knows why this is true, but it has become  
an accepted fact amongst the practitioners of the black arts.

A skeleton, Z, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is a magically-animated undead creature that is part of the zombie monster class. Skeletons resist cold, sleep, poison, death magic, and stoning - they also count as thick-skinned, specifically due to lacking any organic parts.

A skeleton has a weapon attack and a slowing touch that can remove intrinsic speed. Chatting to a skeleton will freeze you in place for a few turns regardless of hostility, and free action will not prevent this.[1]

Generation

Skeletons are not randomly generated, and only appear in Orcus-town, where five will be generated on level creation.[2] Skeletons are always created hostile, and are valid targets for polymorph, e.g. polymorph traps. Polypiling multiple objects made of bone, such as unicorn horns, may also create a skeleton, similar to how golems generate from polypiling other materials.

A normally-generated skeleton has a 1⁄4 chance of generating with leather armor, and an independent 1⁄4 chance of either a knife (2⁄3 chance) or a short sword (1⁄3 chance);[3] they will not be given a random offensive item.

Skeletons do not leave a corpse upon death.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

As of commit f0698e1d, bone devils summon skeletons instead of summoning demons.

Strategy

Skeletons are not a great threat compared to the shades in Orcus Town - their AC is mediocre, and they also lack an MR score. However, their ability to nullify speed still makes them dangerous; their stoning resistance also means that they can wield footrice corpses, so be careful not to leave any near one.

Skeletons make decent pets if you happen to obtain one: they are strong breathless and inediate, can wield weapons and use their touch attack to slow monsters, and have valuable resistances. Unfortunately, they are also slow themselves and cannot wear armor, despite potentially generating with some.

History

The skeleton first appears in NetHack 3.1.0.

==Strategy==
Skeletons are not a great threat compared to the [[shade]]s in Orcus Town - their [[AC]] is mediocre, and they also lack an [[Magic resistance (monster)|MR score]]. However, their ability to nullify speed still makes them dangerous; their stoning resistance also means that they can wield [[footrice]] [[corpses]], so be careful not to leave any near one.

Skeletons make decent [[pet]]s if you happen to obtain one: they are [[strong]] [[breathless]] and [[inediate]], can wield weapons and use their touch attack to slow monsters, and have valuable resistances. Unfortunately, they are also slow themselves and cannot wear armor, despite potentially generating with some.

==History==
The skeleton first appears in [[NetHack 3.1.0]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia}}
{{wikipedia|Skeleton (undead)}}
A skeleton is the structural frame that supports the body of most animals. There are several types of skeletons, such as the exoskeleton (the stable outer shell of an organism); vertebrates have an endoskeleton with a vertical column, which forms a support structure inside the body and is typically composed of bone and cartilage (a rigid connective tissue). Animated skeletons often appear as a type of physically manifested undead in fantasy, gothic and horror fiction, and mythical art. Most such undead are human skeletons, but they can be from any creature or race found on Earth or in the fantasy world.

Animated human skeletons have been used as a personification of death in Western culture since the Middle Ages, perhaps influenced by the valley of the dry bones in the [[wikipedia:Book of Ezekiel|Book of Ezekiel]]. Paintings of The Grim Reaper and Death of the [[Riders|biblical horsemen of the Apocalypse]] have depicted them as skeletons.

Undead skeletons are used extensively in many fantasy role-playing games such as ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]''. The basic skeleton is of the humanoid type and is commonly employed as a low-level undead enemy - they occasionally appear in groups, and are commonly armed with medieval weapons and sometimes armor. Skeletons debut in the 1st Edition Monster Manual of ''Dungeons & Dragons'', where they appear in burial grounds, dungeons and other forsaken areas, and are enchanted with necromantic energy by a powerful evil magic-user or cleric. Skeletons could be given simple commands of 24 words or less by whoever animated, and would attack until they were destroyed; they were immune to mind-affecting spells and cold, and could only be damaged reliably by blunt weapons and fire. Holy water could damage skeletons, and non-evil priests like paladins or clerics could repel or destroy them outright.

==Variants==
In variants that include the [[Convict]] role, a skeleton is generated on the upper filler level(s) of the [[Convict quest]] at level creation.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]] and [[SlashTHEM]], skeletons [[Need +x to hit|require a +2 weapon or better]] to deal damage to them.

A sleeping hostile skeleton is always generated within the prison in the north half of [[Grund's Stronghold]] at level creation.

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], skeletons are resistant to piercing and slashing weapons and vulnerable to blunt weapons.

Skeletons appear as the first [[quest monster]] for [[Binder]]s, and three skeletons are generated as attendants to the third altar on the goal level of the [[Binder quest (dNetHack)|Binder quest]]. Three skeletons appears accompanying a [[death knight]] within one of the rooms in [[Demogorgon]]'s lair if his dwelling appears as [[User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Brine Flats#Demogorgon's palace|the third Abyss level]].

The presence of a [[dread seraph]] on a level causes corpses to rise from the dead as [[Zombie (dNetHack|zombies]] or skeletons. The [[bones]] files of players killed by dread seraphs leave behind skeletons instead of [[ghost]]s.

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], skeletons can be summoned occasionally by [[bone devil]]s, and may drop [[skeleton key]]s made of bone upon death.

If you chat to a skeleton while [[hallucinating]], the resulting bone-rattling will not immobilize you.

===SpliceHack===
In [[SpliceHack-Rewrite]], skeletons have their knife and short sword replaced with a [[parazonium]] and [[gladius]], with the same odds of generating with each weapon.

===SlashTHEM===
In [[SlashTHEM]], in addition to SLASH'EM details above, the second version of the [[Mine king level]] has three skeletons hidden in closets.

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], skeletons have the same odds of generating with a parazonium or gladius as in SpliceHack-Rewrite, and may also drop skeleton keys upon death like in xNetHack.

Grund's Stronghold contains the same sleeping skeleton as in SLASH'EM.
